http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Stagecraft I is a two-semester course which provides students with both exposure to and experience in all elements of technical theatre, including scenery, props, lighting, sound, costume, and makeup. The four strands emphasize creating, performing/presenting, responding and connecting. In Creating, students generate ideas and original tangible works. In Performing and Presenting, students perform tasks associated with technical theatre and present their work to others. Through Responding, students examine works already created by themselves, their peers, or others to analyze the artistic merit and refine work. Through Connecting, students discover connections between theatrical works and historical, societal, and cultural context. Stagecraft I contains foundational elements of theatre that are not developed in Stagecraft II and III, but the teacher may choose to draw student learning expectations from the Drama II-III Curriculum Framework. Stagecraft II is a two-semester course which allows students to advance their skills in all elements of technical theatre through practical experience, with new instruction in design. Stagecraft III is a two-semester course which allows students to deepen their understanding and advance their skills in specialized elements of technical theatre, which could include scenery, props, lighting, sound, costume, and/or makeup. Stagecraft I fulfills the one-half unit of fine arts credit required for graduation. Arkansas Department of Education approval is not required for Stagecraft I, Stagecraft II, or Stagecraft III.
Creating
Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.

Generate a design following the steps of the design process
  • analysis
  • research
  • preliminary sketches
  • finalized sketches, renderings or models
  • related paperwork
Collaborate to prepare a design or stagecraft project
Utilize a design morgue to inform design choices
Students will organize and develop artistic ideas and work.
Develop competencies in various technical roles

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., designer, producer, technician, stage manager

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value:
Utilize appropriate terminology in regard to stage directions
  • center stage
  • downstage
  • stage left
  • stage right
  • upstage
SLE introduced in Stagecraft I. Refer to appropriate level of Drama for optional extension of SLE.
Create selected theatrical paperwork

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., résumé, rehearsal schedule, rehearsal report

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Create selected types of documents used for design and execution

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., ground plans, paint elevations, lighting and sound plots, measurement chart, sketch templates, costume and makeup plots, pull lists

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will refine and complete artistic work.
Apply self-reflection and peer feedback to design choices
Performing/Presenting
Students will select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for presentation.
Utilize analysis of a script of literary merit to select appropriate components to implement a visual/aural design
Examine the manner in which design elements can delineate character relationships in a drama/theatre work
Utilize multiple sources of information (e.g., print resources, web resources, film, video) to inform design choices
SLE introduced in Stagecraft I. Refer to appropriate level of Drama for optional extension of SLE.
Students will develop and refine artistic work for presentation.
Employ research-based technical elements to increase the impact of a presentation
Execute a component of an increasingly complex theatrical design

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., build a set unit, hang/focus light plot, construct a costume piece, style hair, apply makeup

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Analyze the role of the technician and/or designer in the rehearsal process
Develop a theatrical design appropriate for a specific type of theatre space

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., proscenium, thrust, arena, black box

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Utilize the appropriate tools and equipment to execute a component of a theatrical design of scenery and/or property construction
Utilize the appropriate tools and equipment to execute a component of a theatrical design in costume construction
Utilize the appropriate tools and equipment to execute a component of a theatrical design in costume construction and/or makeup/hair styling
Utilize appropriate safety practices in theatre

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., personal protective equipment, proper use of tools and chemicals, situational awareness, exit procedures

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.
Present a theatrical design which utilizes visual and/or aural elements to convey author's intent
Responding
Students will perceive and analyze artistic work.
Analyze dramatic elements of an observed drama/theatre work using theatre terminology
Analyze the contribution of technical elements to the effectiveness of a production
Students will interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.
Distinguish ways design choices impact mood and meaning of a drama/theatre work
Students will apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.
Develop criteria using basic theatre terminology to evaluate performances, designs, and/or execution of designs
Research the manner in which society determines the artistic merit of drama/theatre works
Connecting
Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Evaluate the impact of personal experience on the creation of a design for drama/theatre work
Analyze the influence of personal beliefs and biases on drama/theatre work
Analyze the relevance of various design theories for a drama/theatre work

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., color theory, elements of design, McCandless theory, lighting theory, significant designers

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.
Evaluate artistic choices with regard to societal, cultural, and historical context
Utilize research and technology to make historically and culturally accurate design choices
Employ design elements to convey cultural and historical context of a drama/theatre work
Analyze the influence of community values and beliefs on the design and production of drama/theatre work
Analyze the effect of cultural perspectives on theatrical conventions/practices

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., blackout represents passing of time, set with three walls represents an entire room, soliloquy represents character's internal monologue

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Develop cultural sensitivity to the artistic work of others
Plan a theatre experience, incorporating arts and media
Apply knowledge of theatre history to student-developed stagecraft
Research technological advances in theatre

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., projection, lighting, sound, editing and design software
